exchange.translation[0].definitions[0].d: the act of giving someone something and receiving something else from them
exchange.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Four of my cassettes for your Madonna CD is a fair exchange.
I’ve offered to paint the kitchen in exchange for a week’s accommodation.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[1].d: a short conversation, usually between two people who are angry with each other
exchange.translation[0].definitions[1].e: a quiet exchange between the judge and the clerk
The DJ was fired after a heated exchange  (=a very angry conversation) on air with a call-in listener.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[2].d: the act of giving something you have bought back to the store where you bought it, for example because it does not work, fit etc, and taking something else instead
exchange.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The store’s policy is not to allow returns or exchanges.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[3].d: a process in which you change money from one currency to another
exchange.translation[0].definitions[3].e: Most capital cities have extensive exchange facilities.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[4].d: an arrangement in which a student, teacher etc visits another school or university to work or study
exchange.translation[0].definitions[4].e: I’m here for one term, on an exchange with Dr. Fisher.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[5].d: an arrangement in which you stay in someone’s home, do someone’s job etc for a short time while that person stays in your home, does your job etc
exchange.translation[0].definitions[5].e: Kate’s in New York on an employee exchange so she can get some more training.
exchange.translation[0].definitions[6].d: an event during a war or fight when two people, armies etc shoot or fire missiles at each other
exchange.translation[0].note_box[0].head: – Meaning 2: a short conversation, usually between two people who are angry with each other
exchange.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: There followed a brief exchange between Mitti and Helga in German.
His angry exchange with the referee earned him a yellow card.
I overheard a heated exchange between John and his wife.
The newspaper article led to a series of acrimonious exchanges between leading scientists.
The proposed bill provoked some sharp exchanges in the House of Commons.
There were bitter exchanges between them outside the court room.
The two boxers recently became involved in a heated verbal exchange.
exchange.translation[0].note_box[1].head: – Meaning 5: a process in which you change money from one currency to another
exchange.translation[0].note_box[1].sect: We have seen wide fluctuations in rates of currency exchange this year.
Timber is a vital source of foreign exchange earnings for the country.
What's the current exchange rate between the dollar and the euro?
The pound rose against the dollar on the world foreign currency exchange markets.
The government is going to impose stricter exchange controls.
exchange.translation[0].note_box[2].head: – Meaning 6: an arrangement in which a student, teacher etc visits another school or university to work or study
exchange.translation[0].note_box[2].sect: Our college arranged student exchanges with four colleges in France.
The staff exchange programme allows the company to share personnel with partner institutions abroad.
The mayors of Tokyo and New York signed an agreement to encourage cultural exchanges between the cities.
exchange.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to give someone something and receive the same kind of thing from them at the same time
exchange.translation[1].definitions[0].e: At the end of the game, players traditionally exchange shirts with each other.
exchange.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to give someone something and receive something different from them
exchange.translation[1].definitions[1].e: Where can I exchange my dollars for pounds?
exchange.translation[1].definitions[2].d: to replace one thing with another
exchange.translation[1].definitions[2].e: He exchanged the black jacket for a blue one.
exchange.translation[1].note_box[0].sect: exchange
to give something to someone, and receive a similar thing from them at the same time. Exchange is often used about people telling each other about their ideas, phone numbers, addresses etc
They exchanged photographs before they met.
a place where people can exchange ideas
We exchanged email addresses.
if you are unhappy with the jacket, you can always take it back and exchange it for another one.
These coupons can be exchanged for meals and accommodation.
to exchange something, especially money. Also used in British English about exchanging something you have bought for something different
I need to change some dollars.
She changed all her money into euros.
We thought it was time we changed our car for something more modern.
swap
to give something to someone, who gives you something similar
The two schools use the Internet to swap pictures, stories, and jokes.
I like your room better – do you want to do a swap?
trade
to exchange something that you have for something that someone else has
The stolen phones are being traded for drugs.
The boys trade sports cards on the playground.
We've got lots of plants we don't need – do you want to do a trade?
switch
to change the places of two or more people or things, so that each one is in the place the other was before
Can I switch seats with you?
reciprocate
to do or give something, because someone has done or given something similar to you – a rather formal use
They invited us to dinner a while ago, and I'd like to reciprocate.
in exchange/return (for something)
if you give something in exchange or in return for something else, you give it in order to get something else back
Williams will plead guilty in exchange for a reduced sentence.
exchange.translation[2].definitions[0].d: a market where goods, services, or shares are bought and sold, in return for money
exchange.translation[2].definitions[0].e: the London International Financial Futures Exchange
exchange.translation[2].definitions[1].d: a large building in a town, that was used in the past for buying and selling corn, wool etc
exchange.translation[2].definitions[2].d: the activity of buying and selling currencies
exchange.translation[2].definitions[2].e: We have recently seen the removal of exchange controls (=limits on the amount of currency you are allowed to exchange).
They also made healthy profits in their foreign exchange operations.
exchange.translation[2].definitions[3].d: money in the currency of a foreign country, for example money obtained through exports
exchange.translation[2].definitions[3].e: When oil prices were depressed, Mexico made a great effort to promote manufactured exports as an alternative source of foreign exchange.
The Suez Canal is one of Egypt’s main foreign exchange earners.
exchange.translation[2].definitions[4].d: when you accept one thing in return for another
exchange.translation[2].definitions[4].e: the exchange of goods and services
Tickets cannot be accepted back for exchange or re-sale.
exchange.translation[2].definitions[5].d: an arrangement in which two people from different countries, areas etc do each other’s jobs for a period of time
exchange.translation[2].definitions[5].e: He was on a six-month exchange at the factory where her father was works manager.
exchange.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to give someone something and receive something in return
exchange.translation[3].definitions[0].e: The new system allows marketing data as well as orders and invoices to be exchanged.
Around £2 billion is exchanged for chips in casinos every year.
exchange.translation[3].definitions[1].d: if a shop or company exchanges something you have bought, they take it back and give you a new one, for example because the thing you first bought has a fault
exchange.translation[3].definitions[1].e: The store will not exchange goods without a receipt.
exchange.translation[3].definitions[2].d: if you exchange money, you get money in one currency for money in another
exchange.translation[3].definitions[2].e: Where can I exchange my dollars for pounds?
exchange.translation[3].definitions[3].d: to complete the final stage of buying a house or other property by signing a contract with the person you are buying it from
exchange.translation[3].definitions[3].e: The firm had just exchanged contracts on a nine-acre site.
